title: introduce
text:
ProtVis is a powerful proteomics analysis software designed to provide researchers with an intuitive and efficient tool for protein data analysis. It offers versatile data import options, including formats such as txt, csv, and excel. ProtVis supports differential expression analysis (e.g., limma, t-test) and provides various data normalization methods (e.g., log2, quantile). Additionally, it features dimensionality reduction techniques such as PCA, t-SNE, and UMAP, enabling users to visually explore the structure of their data.
Furthermore, ProtVis integrates k-means clustering, GO/KEGG enrichment analysis, and GSEA analysis, allowing for an in-depth exploration of the biological functions of proteins and their relationships with pathways. For proteomics research focused on post-translational modifications, ProtVis offers visualization and annotation tools, as well as support for the analysis of protein secondary and tertiary structures.
The software supports batch processing and allows for the export of analysis results in formats such as PDF, CSV, and Excel. With its open-source and extensible nature, users can customize and expand the software according to their specific needs. ProtVis simplifies complex analysis workflows through its user-friendly Shiny interface, making it an ideal tool for proteomics research and multi-omics data integration.

title: Installation
text: To install ProtVis from GitHub, run the following command in your R environment:

title: Installation
section: Method 1: Load the package and run
text:
Method 1: Load the package and run
library(ProtVis)
run_ProtVis()

title: Installation
text:
Method 2: Directly call the function
ProtVis::run_ProtVis()
This will open the interactive GUI for proteomics and PTM analysis.

title: Release Data
text:
In the process of data analysis using ProtVis, each step generates intermediate .rda files in the working directory. If users wish to view, export, or reuse the data from any specific step, the Release Data module provides an intuitive interface for exporting these .rda files into common tabular formats (e.g., CSV, Excel).
This guide outlines the steps to use this module effectively.

title: Release Data
text:
Step-by-Step Instructions

Step 1: Set the Working Directory
The current working directory path is displayed at the top of the interface. Ensure that this path is correctly set to where your .rda files are stored.
ðŸ“Œ Example:


Step 2: Load .rda Files
Click the LOAD .RDA FILES button to scan and display all available .rda files under the current working directory.


Step 3: Select Files to Export
Check one or more .rda files that you want to export.
For example:
- âœ… Step1_project_init.rda
- âœ… Step2_remove_unreliable_peptide.rda
These files contain intermediate data from various analysis stages such as project initialization, data cleaning, noise correction, etc.


Step 4: Choose Output Format
Select the desired export format from the dropdown menu: - csv (Comma-Separated Values) - tsv (Tab-Separated Values) - xlsx (Excel format)


Step 5: Export the Data
Click the EXPORT button to download the selected .rda files in the chosen format. This makes it easier to inspect the intermediate data or share it with collaborators.

title: Release Data
text:
Module Screenshot


âœ… Tip: Exported .xlsx or .csv files can be opened with Excel, R, Python, or any spreadsheet viewer for further analysis or review.
